natural problem: Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "char list"
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c]"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {xs . length xs = 3 \<and> distinct xs \<and> sorted xs \<and> set xs = {a, b, c}}) div (card {xs . length xs = 3 \<and> distinct xs \<and> set xs = {a, b, c}})"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "char list"
assumes h0 : "distinct [a, b, c]"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {xs . length xs = 3 \<and> distinct xs \<and> sorted xs \<and> set xs = {a, b, c}}) div (card {xs . length xs = 3 \<and> distinct xs \<and> set xs = {a, b, c}})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability that a distinct 3-element set, chosen from a pool of three unique elements denoted by a, b, and c, will be sorted in ascending order? The final answer is 1/6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 1 / (fact 3)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 1 / (fact 3)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "Given that P equals the reciprocal of the factorial of 3, demonstrate that P equals one-sixth."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "string list"
assumes h0 : "length students = 3"
and h1 : "distinct students"
and h2 : "students = sort students"
shows  "1 / 6 = (1 :: real) / (fact (length students))"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "string list"
assumes h0 : "length students = 3"
and h1 : "distinct students"
and h2 : "students = sort students"
shows  "1 / 6 = (1 :: real) / (fact (length students))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If there are 3 different students, what is the probability that when they are sorted (possibly alphabetically), they appear in their original order? The final answer is 1/6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "'a set"
and line_up :: "'a list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "finite students"
and h1 : "card students = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> l. line_up l = (l = sort l)"
and h3 : "let l = THE l. line_up l in length l = 3"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {l. line_up l} div card {l. length l = 3})"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "'a set"
and line_up :: "'a list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "finite students"
and h1 : "card students = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> l. line_up l = (l = sort l)"
and h3 : "let l = THE l. line_up l in length l = 3"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {l. line_up l} div card {l. length l = 3})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Assume there are 3 students in a line. What is the probability that the students are lined up in ascending order? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (1 / fact 3)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
a_4.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (1 / fact 3)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Determine the value of P if P is defined as the reciprocal of the factorial of 3. The final answer is 1/6.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1 / (fact n)"
shows  "probability 3 = 1 / 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1 / (fact n)"
shows  "probability 3 = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: The probability function is defined such that for any number n greater than 0, the probability of n is 1 divided by the factorial of n. What is the probability of 3? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "'a set" and order :: "'a list"
assumes h0 : "finite students"
and h1 : "distinct order"
and h2 : "set order = students"
and h3 : "length order = 3"
and h4 : "\<forall> i < length order - 1. order ! i \<le> order ! (i+1)"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {order. distinct order \<and> set order = students \<and> length order = 3 \<and> (\<forall> i < length order - 1. order ! i \<le> order ! (i+1))}) / fact (card students)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "'a set" and order :: "'a list"
assumes h0 : "finite students"
and h1 : "distinct order"
and h2 : "set order = students"
and h3 : "length order = 3"
and h4 : "\<forall> i < length order - 1. order ! i \<le> order ! (i+1)"
shows  "1 / 6 = (card {order. distinct order \<and> set order = students \<and> length order = 3 \<and> (\<forall> i < length order - 1. order ! i \<le> order ! (i+1))}) / fact (card students)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Suppose we have a distinct group of students. If we arrange these students in an order such that each student is not greater than the next, there are 3 possible ways to arrange them. What is the probability that a randomly selected arrangement will be in ascending order? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "students = 3"
shows  "1 / (fact students) = 1/6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three students, with different names, line up single file. What is the probability that they are in alphabetical order from front-to-back?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are six ways to line up: $ABC$, $ACB$, $BAC$, $BCA$, $CAB$, $CBA$, and only one of these is in alphabetical order front-to-back. The probability is one in six or $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "students = 3"
shows  "1 / (fact students) = 1/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given that there are 3 students, find the value of the reciprocal of the factorial of the number of students. The final answer is 1/6.
